Unnamed: 1: Meaning
Unnamed: 6: Explanation

Unnamed: 1: Not applicable or not present in requirements
Unnamed: 6: These criteria are essential to platform qualification. If these are missing, the solution likely cannot be considered a platform. Examples: Scope & Reusability, Ecosystem Enablement, Multi-Use-Case Support.

Unnamed: 1: Minimal alignment — some potential but mostly specific to a single use/application
Unnamed: 6: These traits enhance platform quality but are not standalone proof of a platform. They often indicate maturity, scale, or enterprise readiness. Examples: Developer Experience, Security & Compliance, Cross-Domain Applicability.

Unnamed: 1: Partial alignment — reusable or extensible components but not fully ecosystem-ready
Unnamed: 6: Important for operability, maintainability, and ease of adoption, but not central to defining a platform. These are often technical enablers or maintenance features.Examples: Upgradeability & Versioning, Migration Readiness.

Unnamed: 1: Strong alignment — clear platform traits, multi-use, reusable, and scalable architecture
Questions/Vocabulary
Unnamed: 6: Industry Group specific Examples
Unnamed: 8: Sample RFP/BRD Text to Identify Platform Trait

Unnamed: 1: Does the solution provide reusable frameworks, services, or APIs that multiple teams/apps can build upon?
Unnamed: 6:
• EV: Telematics API for diagnostics across vehicle models
• Healthcare: Shared patient identity service for multiple hospital systems
Unnamed: 7:
• Microsoft: Azure AD B2C identity platform for 
all apps
• Java/Open Source: Spring Boot microservice scaffold published to Nexus
• Use of Authentication/ UMS service
• SSO enablement for the users
Unnamed: 8: Platform to serve as a foundation for multiple business apps or services

Unnamed: 1: Can third parties or internal users build on top of the platform (not just consume it)?
Unnamed: 6:
• Banking & Finance: Open Banking hub connecting
 multiple banks and fintechs
• GBS/GenAI: AI co-pilot marketplace 
for customer service partners
Unnamed: 7:
• Open Source: Apache Kafka Connect plugin ecosystem
• Process Automation: UiPath Marketplace for reusable automation components
Unnamed: 8: Partners or clients will develop add-ons, extensions, or apps

Unnamed: 1: Can the platform support multiple apps/use cases from the same foundation?
Unnamed: 6:
• Healthcare: Clinical trial portal and telehealth on same platform
• IoT: Predictive maintenance and fleet tracking on a single IoT platform
Unnamed: 7: • Serverless: Functions framework powering both webhooks and batch jobs (e.g., Azure Functions)
Unnamed: 8: Enable multiple business processes/use cases through one core system

Unnamed: 1:
Is there a requirement for 
the platform to scale to support
 increasing users, applications, or data 
volumes while maintaining resilience?
Will the platform scale to thousands of tenants, millions of requests, with built-in HA/failover?
Unnamed: 6:
• EV Charging: Global charging network platform 
with load balancing , scheduling etc
Unnamed: 8: Expected to support thousands of tenants or millions of requests

Unnamed: 1: Does it support secure, isolated use by multiple tenants or customers on shared infra?
Unnamed: 6: Shared data lake across business units
Unnamed: 7: • Kubertnetes - enabling multi-tenant cluster with limiting resource quotas
Unnamed: 8: Support for multiple clients or BUs on a shared infrastructure

Unnamed: 1: Does it need to integrate with external or internal systems via APIs, connectors, etc.?
Unnamed: 6:
• Manufacturing: MES integration with SAP and custom factory systems
• Insurance: Policy system integration with claims platforms
Unnamed: 7:
• Logic Apps: Prebuilt connectors to SAP, Salesforce
• Webhooks: Standard REST hooks for real-time events
Unnamed: 8: Must integrate with ERP, CRM, legacy apps, or external APIs

Unnamed: 1: Does scope involve infra transformation like cloud migration or replatforming?
Unnamed: 6: On-prem to AWS or Azure
Unnamed: 8: Includes cloud migration or infra modernization scope

Unnamed: 1: Are metrics, logs, traces, and dashboards required for platform visibility?
Unnamed: 6:
• Financial Services: Real-time trading 
platform telemetry routed to Splunk
• Renewables: Energy production 
monitoring on wind-farm platform
Unnamed: 7:
• OpenTelemetry: Enabling Distributed tracing across microservices
• Prometheus & Grafana: Metrics and dashboards
Unnamed: 8: Monitoring, tracing, alerts required for multi-service architecture

Unnamed: 1: Does the platform expose APIs, SDKs, or webhooks for extensions or automation?
Unnamed: 6: • Gaming:  webhooks for wallet transactions• Retail: E-commerce platform webhooks for order status updates on mobiles or other devices
Unnamed: 7: OpenAPI: Code generation for client SDKs through use of Gen AI tools
Unnamed: 8: Expose APIs, SDKs, Webhooks for integrations and extensibility

Unnamed: 1: Is the platform designed for internal or external developers to self-serve efficiently?
Unnamed: 6:
• Process Automation: RPA script recorder and debugger
IDP portals for self servicing developers
Unnamed: 8: Internal Developer Portal (IDP) and CI/CD automation needed

Unnamed: 1: Must the platform provide shared security features for built-on apps?
Unnamed: 6: Central auth for multiple modules
Unnamed: 8: Built-in security, audit logging, and regulatory compliance

Unnamed: 1: Is it usable across different business units or domains?
Unnamed: 6: Analytics CoE serving Finance + HR
Unnamed: 7: Shared ML pipelines or CI/CD templates
Unnamed: 8: Shared services accessible across departments or product lines

Unnamed: 1: Is the solution aligned with a SaaS/ISV model (sold or licensed for building on top)?
Unnamed: 6: B2B SaaS platform sold to partners
Unnamed: 8: To be offered as SaaS to third-party customers or other teams

Unnamed: 1:
Does the system need to 
be highly flexible and 
customizable to meet 
varying customer requirements?
Unnamed: 6:
• Banking: Rule-engine for credit eligibility
• Healthcare: No-code clinical pathway builder
Unnamed: 8: Users must customize workflows, UI, or rules per customer

Checklist to identify Platform Engineeri:
Ease of Use/
Ease of onboarding
Unnamed: 1:
Can new developers/customers 
get started in minutes via 
docs, CLI, quickstarts, 
sandbox?
Unnamed: 6:
• Analytics CoE: Self-service Power BI 
sandbox with sample datasets
• Mobile Apps: Developer program 
for rapid SDK onboarding
Unnamed: 7:
• YAML Generators: Project scaffolding for microservices
• Cloud Templates: ARM/Bicep or Terraform modules
Unnamed: 8: Quick onboarding with sandbox, CLI, starter templates, docs

Unnamed: 1: Are controls needed to enforce compliance, access, and usage across tenants?
Unnamed: 6:
• Healthcare: Data access policies with 
HIPAA audit trails
• Banking: Role-based compliance for transaction approvals
Unnamed: 8: Policy enforcement and access control across modules required

Unnamed: 1: Does it require backward-compatible upgrades and controlled deprecations?
Unnamed: 6: API lifecycle management in ISVs
Unnamed: 8: Rolling updates, versioning support without downtime needed

Unnamed: 1: Does the platform hide complex infra or workflows for dev/user simplicity?
Unnamed: 6: Infra abstraction layer for dev teams
Unnamed: 8: Hide orchestration complexity from dev teams or end users

Unnamed: 1: Will it help unify dev practices or architecture across teams?
Unnamed: 6: Shared delivery pipeline for microservices
Unnamed: 8: Define reusable standards across product or infra teams

Unnamed: 1: Interpretation
Minimal platform traits — likely a custom or point application
Some reusable or multi-use elements — consider modularizing further
High platform potential — reusable, multi-tenant, some ecosystem signs
Fully qualified platform — reusable, extensible, scalable, ecosystem-ready
